bibl.title: Letter from Mazyck P. Ravenel to William S. Thayer, April 26, 1926

div1.p: Ravenel writes that he doubts the influence of Carter's work on Reed. He believes Reed was inspired by Finlay.

div1.head: Letter from Mazyck P. Ravenel to William S. Thayer, April 26, 1926
div1.opener:
Copy.
(Confidential: not to be used)
University of Missouri,
Columbia.
April 26, 1926.
Bacteriology and Preventive Medicine
Dr. W. S. Thayer,
1208 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Maryland.
My dear Dr. Thayer:
div1.p:
I am very much obliged to you for your letter of April 19th., enclos-
ing a copy of your letter to Miss Carter under date of April 14th.

I had the pleasure and honor of knowing Dr. Reed quite well and he
told me personally a good deal about his work in Cuba, though I cannot re-
call his having discussed the particular point in which I have been inter-
ested. The information upon which I based my statements was not taken en-
tirely from Kelly's book, though I did consult it and used some of the
statements made by Reed himself which Dr. Kelly reproduced. I, therefore,
do not think that anything I took from Kelly's book is misleading, or that
I have obtained any incorrect ideas from it.

I knew Dr. Carter for a great many years and was one of his great
admirers. I would, therefore, be the last one to wish to belittle anything
that he did, and my own interest in this entire matter has been to get the
truth. I wrote a letter to “Science” hoping that it would bring out corres-
pondence and possibly some definite facts which would prove the matter one
way or the other. After the material was in print, I determined to suppress
it on account of the letters from Miss Carter and other material sent to
me by General Cumming. Professor Cattell has asked me to write more fully
on the subject and sometime or other I may do so, though probably I will not.

The matter seems to me to be entirely beyond an absolute settlement.
Reed told me personally, what he published a number of times, that he went
to Finlay, got all of his ideas, and even the larvae from which the experi-
mental mosquitoes were grown. It is, therefore, inconceivable that Reed did
not know all of Finlay's work. It is equally inconceivable to me that a man
Dr. "W. S. Thayer
-2-
April 26, 1926
(Copy: confidential)
man
like Reed would start on an investigation of this kind without a full knowl-
edge of all that had been done before, but in this I may be mistaken. You
will remember also Reed's own account of the death of the prisoner from
yellow fever, one of a half dozen or more who had been confined in a small
jail for approximately the same length of time, and none of whom had been ex
posed to infection, as it was then understood. Reed surmised that the only
possible source of infection was an insect which could have gotten in through
the window.

I do not bring these things up to argue over the facts you have given
me, and I am entirely disposed to accept all that you say without question.
I am entirely willing to believe that Carter's observations had much to do
with Reed's latter investigation, but it seems to me equally clear that other
things influenced him also. It seems to me that we are entirely in accord,
as far as the facts go. You admit that “there is not the slightest doubt”
that Finlay's observation led them to study the mosquito at the outset, and
this I know also from Reed's own lips.

I wonder if General Cumming ever showed Miss Carter the obituary notice
I wrote for the A. J. P. H. of her Father? I asked him to show it to her as
I was satisfied that it would show her that I was not trying to detract from
the excellent work he did. If you have not read it yourself, I wish you
would do so. It is in November, 1925, issue of the A. J. P. H., page 994.

I would like to discuss this matter further in the public prints for the
sake of getting all of the material possible on it, but I can readily under-
stand how Miss Carter and other members of the family feel, and I would not
for the world do anything to hurt them, so that for the present at least, I
have decided not to say anything more about it.
With kind regards and thanking you, I am,
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, (Signed) Mazyck P. Ravenel,
Mazyck P. Ravenel, M. D. MPR:LP
P. S. I have always felt that Finlay had been unjustly deprived of credit due
